meanings.def: to break or press something into very small pieces between two hard surfaces or using a special machine
examples: to grind coffee/corn
The animal has teeth that grind its food into a pulp.
The cement need not be finely ground.
The coffee is ground to a fine powder.
freshly ground black pepper
machinery for grinding wheat into flour

meanings.def: to produce something such as flour by grinding
examples: The flour is ground using traditional methods.

meanings.def: to cut food, especially meat, into very small pieces using a special machine (called a mincer)
to make something sharp or smooth by rubbing it against a hard surface
examples: a special stone for grinding knives

meanings.def: to press or rub something into a surface
examples: grind something into something He ground his cigarette into the ashtray.
grind something in The dirt on her hands was ground in.

meanings.def: to rub together, or to make hard objects rub together, often producing an unpleasant noise
examples: grind (together) Parts of the machine were grinding together noisily.
grind something (together) She grinds her teeth when she is asleep.
He ground the gears on the car.

meanings.def: to turn the handle of a machine that grinds something
examples: to grind a pepper mill

meanings.def: to make something gradually go slower until it stops completely
examples: Roadworks brought traffic to a grinding halt.

meanings.def: to go slower gradually and then stop completely
examples: Production ground to a halt during the strike.
Her career ground to a halt when the twins were born.

meanings.def: to have private reasons for being involved in something or for arguing for a particular cause
examples: She had no axe to grind and was only acting out of concern for their safety.
These criticisms are commonly voiced by those who have some political axe to grind.

idioms.idiom: bring something to a grinding halt
idioms.def: to make something gradually go slower until it stops completely
examples: Roadworks brought traffic to a grinding halt.

idioms.idiom: grind to a halt | come to a grinding halt
idioms.def: to go slower gradually and then stop completely
examples: Production ground to a halt during the strike.
Her career ground to a halt when the twins were born.

idioms.def: to have private reasons for being involved in something or for arguing for a particular cause
examples: She had no axe to grind and was only acting out of concern for their safety.
These criticisms are commonly voiced by those who have some political axe to grind.

meanings.def: an activity that is boring or makes you tired and takes a lot of time
examples: the daily grind of family life
It's a long grind to the top of that particular profession.

meanings.def: the unpleasant noise made by machines
a person who spends too much time studying
